conclusion: Understanding how the position and size of shadows change when the light source moves.
The key factors are the distance of the light source from the objects and the angle at which the light hits the objects.
The light source is initially positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The shadows are formed by the projection of the objects onto the ground.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
As the light source moves backward, the angle at which the light hits the objects will change.
The shadow will become smaller and further away from the objects.
The shadows will move further away from the objects.
In the initial image, the shadows are closer to the objects and have a certain size.
In the second image, the shadows are further away from the objects and appear smaller.
This confirms that the light source has moved backward.
When the light source moves backward, the shadows A, B, C, and D will move further away from the objects and become smaller in size.
